posts.name: I do everything because small team
posts.cooked: I am a member of a first-year, very small team in Iowa. We’ve gotten most things figured out up to this point, but we’re having a lot of trouble getting our gyro to work. it’s just plugged into the spi port. the power light comes on when the robot is on but the ready light doesn’t. when we run the example program in LabVIEW it says that the device is not found. any ideas are greatly appreciated.
posts.display_username: I do everything because small team

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked:
Is the RIO Power light green? It will be red if there is a short to the various power anywhere.

This is what the example looks like when you get it working: XRS450 SPI Gyro Example 1250×907 127 KB

XRS450 SPI Gyro Example 1250×907 127 KB

XRS450 SPI Gyro Example 1250×907 127 KB

posts.name: I do everything because small team
posts.cooked: Yes, the Rio power is green. Every time we run the example the device found light is red.
posts.display_username: I do everything because small team

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked:
Here’s what my lights look like so you can double check if there is anything different. Gyro SPI roboRIO 1000×750 94.8 KB

Gyro SPI roboRIO 1000×750 94.8 KB

Gyro SPI roboRIO 1000×750 94.8 KB

The mode light isn’t really on. That’s just bleed over from the really bright RSL light. So only the Power and RSL lights should be on.

reply_to_user.name: I do everything because small team

posts.name: I do everything because small team
posts.cooked: Yeah ours looks pretty much the same
posts.display_username: I do everything because small team

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked:
Any bent pins on the SPI port? Any metal shavings caught under the pins? Have you been working on the robot over unprotected electronics, for instance, have a cover over the electronics to protect it from metal dust and shavings)?

I assume as a rookie team that you have a new roboRIO 2.0.

reply_to_user.name: I do everything because small team

posts.name: I do everything because small team
posts.cooked: Just was able to check and it I haven’t found anything that would have shorted. I also made sure to clean it just in case
posts.display_username: I do everything because small team

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked:
I thought I heard from one of my co-mentors that there was an issue with the KOP gyro and RIO2.   That’s why we went to a Pigeon 2.0.

Might do a search in CD and see.

I tried and didn’t find anything specific about it not being compatible.  But this is what I did find.

ADXSR450 Gyroscope is not working Programming

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked: It works fine for me obviously from the earlier demo I posted.

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked: Well, guess I wasted my money.

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked: The link I posted mentions needing to make sure the jumpers are in the right place.  I remember that messed us up once when we didn’t have it in the right place.

reply_to_user.name: I do everything because small team

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked:
If the gyro is at a different SPI address because of a jumper or solder, then the example code would not work as is. By default it does expect to find the gyro at it’s default SPI address. You can test the other addresses just in case by clicking on the “SPI Bus” input that you set before running the example.

Look at the board and the jumper/solder pins should be labeled as “CS0”, “CS1”, or “CS2” and you do need at least one of those selected by jumper.

posts.name: I do everything because small team
posts.cooked: If I’m being honest I didn’t know that the jumpers existed. I’ll try that tomorrow and see what happens.
posts.display_username: I do everything because small team
